body: EARLY on in his furniture designing career, which is to say just about a year or two ago, Hughes N'Cho-Allépot found a seasoned carpenter to make his pieces. title: Habitats; Designer's Bushwick Loft Showcases His Furniture

body: THE holiday season is generally the time to reconnect with family and friends, but at a party on Dec. 20 at a loft in Bushwick, Brooklyn, few of the guests had met previously -- at least not in person. They knew each other as subscribers to Suicidegirls.com, a Web site founded in 2001 that costs members $4 a year and features photographs of about
title: GOOD COMPANY; Connected by a Web Site, With Erotica Played Down

body: The lights were burning bright at City Hall yesterday. Edward Skyler, the mayor's press secretary, was at his desk. Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw was at his. But the whereabouts of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was a bit of a mystery. Was he in New York City, New York State or even the United States? No one at City Hall would say, even though that left
title: Where's the Mayor? Not Your Business, Staff Says

body: Five months after Chancellor Joel I. Klein admitted that the New York City schools were wrongly pushing out many struggling high school students, the Department of Education says it has turned around its handling of students who have fallen behind and are not expected to graduate on time. ''Discharges are absolutely down for the period ending Dec.
title: Schools Reduce the Number of Students They Force to Leave Early

body: It was the worst real-estate portfolio imaginable: ten thousand of New York City's most woebegone buildings, all of them in tax arrears, vacant, burned out or occupied by some of the city's poorest tenants in its most addled neighborhoods. A hundred thousand apartments held by a landlord with hardly any money for repairs and, it seemed, hardly any
title: One Housing Woe Gives Way to Another; New York Is No Longer Awash in Abandoned Buildings. Now the Issue Is Supply.

body: It's the year 2103 and Brooklyn remains a vibrant, bustling borough thanks in no small part to the fortitude and creativity of a century's worth of immigrants. Some things, however, have changed. For several generations now, Bedford-Stuyvesant has been predominantly Latino, while East New York and Brownsville residents come mostly from India. These
title: Where the Streets Have Too Many Names

title: Council Proposes 2 Moves to Intensify City's War on Rats

title: CITYPEOPLE; Gliding Along, And Gathering A City's Castoffs

title: About New York; Stale Harvest: Marketing a Party Boss

body: Officer Wilton Sekzer was in the living room of his apartment in Sunnyside, Queens, on the night of July 13, 1977, when his lights went out. On the way to check his fuse box, he peeked out the window. The whole block was dark. Sekzer ran up three flights to his roof. He looked to the west, across the East River, to Manhattan. The familiar shapes of
title: The Darkest Night

title: Born To Be Mild

title: All Council Incumbents Win Their Primary Races, Despite Many Challenges

title: Council Chief Gives Support Others Can Hum To

title: 2 Are Charged Anew In Death of Daughter

title: For Civil Court

title: Mayor Hails 'New Era' in Schools Amid Crowding Fears

body: Two years ago, Diana Reyna won a spirited, three-way City Council primary by one of the smallest victory margins of the 2001 Democratic Council contests. title: On the Border, a Rematch With a Difference

body: In two unrelated murder-suicides in Brooklyn, a young couple and an elderly couple were found dead in their homes yesterday, the police said. The bodies were discovered yesterday afternoon in Bushwick and Greenpoint. The police said the men had killed the women, then themselves. In Bushwick, at 168 Bleecker Street, a man shot and killed his
title: 2 Couples Found Shot Dead In Separate Murder-Suicides

body: A 3-year-old Brooklyn girl who suffered a skull fracture and was so malnourished that court papers described her as ''skin and bones'' died yesterday morning. Before the child died, her parents were arrested on abuse charges, but now they could face more serious charges. Officials said yesterday that a grand jury will begin this week to weigh
title: After Brooklyn Girl Dies, More Charges Are Weighed

body: Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday that the Fire Department would transfer 20 firefighters with the most sick leave absences to other assignments in an effort to stem what he called abuses of its medical leave policy. The measures may seem counterintuitive: the firefighters will be moved from busy firehouses to less busy ones,
title: The Biggest Users of Sick Leave Face Transfer in Fire Department

body: The 3-year-old Brooklyn girl weighed only 16 pounds when she was taken to the hospital. She was covered in bruises and had a skull fracture. There was a burn on her chest, possibly from a cigarette. Last night, her condition was so grave that the authorities feared that she would not live until morning, several investigators said. The girl's
title: Questions Surround Battered Brooklyn 3-Year-Old

body: New Yorkers who lived through the arson and looting that ravaged the city during the blackout of 1977 were understandably edgy when the lights went out on Aug. 14. But it was clear by late evening that the blackout of 2003 would be nothing like its predecessor. This night did not belong to arsonists or looters; it belonged to families and neighbors
title: Editorial Observer; Why Once-Violent Neighborhoods Stayed Calm During the Blackout

body: Even in these days of computer games, conditioned air and liability lawsuits, the people of New York still go to the roof. They charge through security doors and climb up fire escapes, and nervous landlords or busybody building superintendents are no match. They go seeking cool relief, a little conversation, the spectacular belvedere from what
title: On the Roof, Another New York, Above It All

body: One of the axioms of New York City politics is that incumbents do not lose elections. But that notion was disproved a year ago, when Nellie R. Santiago, then a state senator, became one of the few elected officials to lose a Democratic primary for re-election, in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. title: COUNCIL CONTESTS: 37th District/Brooklyn; In Brooklyn, Ex-State Senator Challenges Son of Man Who Sent Her Home From Albany

body: When the lights went out on Thursday, Imani Kuumba was in an eyeglass shop on 116th Street in Harlem. She was also in a very different New York from the one she lived in when the last major blackout in 1977 turned her South Bronx neighborhood into a harrowing zone of plunder and mayhem. In 1977, ''it was complete chaos, just total chaos,'' Ms.
title: THE BLACKOUT: LOOKING BACK; In Calm Blackout, Views of Remade City

title: THE BLACKOUT: THE NEIGHBORHOODS; For Owners of Stores Hit by Looters, Low Crime Rate During Crisis Is No Comfort

body: A 20-year-old woman was found shot to death yesterday morning in a park in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the police said. A passer-by found the body of Julisa Feliciano shortly after 1 a.m. in Irving Square Park, a small city park regarded by neighbors as dangerous after dark. There were no arrests, and the motive for the killing was unknown, the police said
title: Slain Woman Is Found in a Brooklyn Park

body: Fires started by candles and generators during the power blackout led to one of the busiest nights since the 1970's for the New York Fire Department, officials said yesterday. title: THE BLACKOUT: FIRES; Three Are Killed as Blazes Erupt Across the Northeast

title: The Word on the Street? For New York's Rats, It's 'Goodbye'

title: THE BLACKOUT OF 2003: The Overview; POWER SURGE BLACKS OUT NORTHEAST, HITTING CITIES IN 8 STATES AND CANADA; MIDDAY SHUTDOWNS DISRUPT MILLIONS

body: There was, before yesterday, the good blackout and the bad blackout: the 15-hour power loss beginning on the evening of Nov. 9, 1965, that was largely characterized by cooperation and overriding good cheer and the 25-hour one beginning on the sticky night of July 13, 1977, that was defined by widespread looting and arson in the city's poorer
title: THE BLACKOUT OF 2003: THE PAST; The Blackouts of '65 and '77 Became Defining Moments in the City's History

title: THE BLACKOUT OF 2003; Brooklyn, Revisited

body: The most grueling would-be event at the Pan American Games involves a torch, running, shooting and crying. It's called Peaceful Protest, and it is definitely not sanctioned. title: BackTalk; Protesting Through the Streets

body: Even for New York City, it was a bizarre specter: a firehouse closed because it had been taken over by rats. On Tuesday, the city temporarily relocated the firefighters and ordered that the
title: A Detested Emblem of Decay Is Scurrying Back. Ah, Rats!

title: Brooklyn Bishop Ending Tenure Amid Storm Over Scandal

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BUSHWICK; Over a Neighborhood's Sunny Spot, a Shadow Looms

title: About New York; Claws Over Broadway

title: Habitats/West 33rd Street; For Minister, His Church Is Home, in Many Ways

title: AT HOME WITH: Justin Theroux; The Joy Of Junk

body: THE pungent aroma of boiling barley and hops is long gone. Long gone, as well, are the six-keg-high phalanxes of beer barrels in the storage yard, the single-file march of cans and bottles below their filling spouts, the fleet of gothic-lettered delivery trucks. Rising now on the 6.7-acre Rheingold Brewery site in Bushwick, Brooklyn -- a community
title: Something's Brewing in Bushwick

body: Acknowledging that obesity is epidemic among New York City schoolchildren, the Education Department is reducing the fat content in the 800,000 meals it serves daily and banning candy, soda and other sugary snacks from school vending machines. Gone may be lunchroom staples like beef ravioli, potato salad and macaroni and cheese; the department has
title: Schools Cut Down on Fat and Sweets in Menus

body: For months Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg argued that closing eight firehouses was politically tough but necessary to balance the city's budget. He held to that line in the face of political attacks, private entreaties, emotional rallies and even lawsuits. But this week the mayor agreed to spare two of the firehouses after heavy lobbying from the State
title: Bloomberg Says Merits, Not Politics, Saved Firehouses

body: A 22-year-old Army specialist from Brooklyn was killed in Iraq on Sunday when another soldier's gun discharged, the authorities said. The victim, Specialist Rasheed Sahib, died from a bullet wound to his chest in the town of Balad, Iraq, according to The Associated Press. It said that the gun discharged when it was being cleaned by a fellow
title: Soldier From Brooklyn Dies When Hit by a Bullet in Iraq

body: After the State Legislature passed a New York City aid package yesterday over the veto of Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reversed course and said that the city would be able to save two of the eight city firehouses that were scheduled to close. The mayor's turnaround came after he and his aides insisted for months that the
title: Mayor Spares 2 Threatened Firehouses After All

body: A 21-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in a shooting at a Brooklyn barbershop last month, the police said. Two brothers were shot in the April 3 attack. One of them, Kawane Buckner, was hit in the back of the head and died on April 27 at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens. The police said the two men were shot
title: Arrest in Killing At a Barbershop

body: The prevailing political theory at City Hall goes something like this: Politics do not matter. If Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg remains true to his convictions, resists the taint of special interest groups and makes tough choices that keep the city sound, New Yorkers will appreciate and reward him. But that theory is being severely tested as Mr.
title: BUDGETS IN CRISIS: CITY HALL MEMO; No Politician? The Polls Agree With the Mayor

title: SUMMER FESTIVALS; POP/JAZZ

body: Less than a year after she lost her State Senate seat, Nellie Santiago, a Brooklyn Democrat who was in the Senate for a decade, is returning to politics. title: Ex-Senator Is Challenging Son Of the Man Who Ousted Her

body: Janette and her husband, Juan, have a continuing argument about taxes. It is not about who is keeping track of the receipts or who should call the accountant. They are illegal immigrants, and what they cannot agree about is whether to file an income tax return. Once a middle-class professional in Peru, Juan now works in a restaurant in Nassau
title: Tax Day Puts Illegal Immigrants in a Special Bind

title: Commute to Nowhere

body: Two men who the police believe were bent on robbery walked into a Brooklyn barbershop late Thursday night after it had closed and shot the owner and his brother, critically wounding both men, the authorities said yesterday. After the crime, the attackers apparently pulled down the security gate at the shop, P. J.'s Splitt Ends, at 379 Bushwick
title: 2 Brothers Critically Wounded By Shots in Brooklyn Barbershop

White did not have romantic notions about military life -- at least none he shared with his cousin Althea Russell-Muse, who was just two years older than he, and in their small family, was practically a sister. title: A NATION AT WAR: NEW YORK; Marine, 24, Saw Corps as a Steppingstone

body: A bill on lead poisoning has been stalled in the City Council for a year, even though more than half the council members support it. A report to be released today suggests that large campaign contributions from the real estate industry may be holding it up. City council members have received $160,000 from members of real estate trade organizations
title: Report Ties Donations to Lead-Paint Law's Delay

title: FALLEN OFFICERS: THE VICTIMS; Focused At Work, But Devoted To Children

The report, by New York Acorn, found that in 10 neighborhoods with a great deal of vacant land, 66 percent of the
title: City-Sold Lots Stay Vacant, Report Says

title: CITY LORE; Demure Beauties of Old

title: For a Stretch of Brooklyn Waterfront, Many Dreams Are Contenders

title: Homeless Man Is Charged With Slashing on Subway Platform

body: New York City is facing an epidemic of diabetes, health officials said yesterday, pointing to new figures showing that nearly 8 percent of adults in the city have the disease, double the rate of eight years ago. This rate, which mirrors national trends, is particularly high in the city's poorest neighborhoods, where obesity rates are also extremely
title: Diabetes Rate Has Doubled, City Reports

A man approached her from behind, forced her into a car and drove her to an unknown
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teenage Girl Reported Raped

title: Tears and Questions After Boy's Fatal Collapse at School

body: On any ordinary Sunday morning, Ana Lucia Rodriguez would have been listening avidly to the sermon in her accustomed spot in the second row at St. Martin of Tours Roman Catholic Church in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Yesterday, she had become the sermon. The Rev. Patrick Burns struggled to tame the anguish of his congregation after they learned that Ms.
title: Woman Killed by Police Car Is Recalled as 'Heart of Parish'

body: A woman was struck and killed last night by an unmarked police car that was responding to the scene of an unrelated shooting in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said. The woman, Lucia Rodriguez, 63, of 218 Palmetto Street, was hit shortly before 6 p.m. on Wilson Avenue between Menahan and Grove Streets, according to the police. The car
title: Brooklyn Woman Killed by Police Car
